header.title: Gear Ratio Calculator
header.description: Enter tooth counts and input speed to estimate ratio, output speed, and torque (incl. efficiency).

card.title: Gear Ratio Calculator
card.description: Enter tooth counts and input speed; the tool calculates ratio, output speed, and torque (incl. efficiency).

gearRatio.note: Note: Output torque includes efficiency factor η.

header.title: Simply Supported Beam — Bending Stress & Deflection
header.description: Compute bending moment, section modulus, bending stress, and deflection for a simply supported beam with a central point load.

results.title: Results
results.note: Formulas assume a simply supported beam with a mid-span point load. Verify against applicable standards for critical designs.

notes.title: Design notes
notes.empty: Complete the inputs and the notes will update automatically.

safety.veryLow: Very low safety. Risky with tolerances and load uncertainty.
safety.low: Low safety. Acceptable for prototype checks; review for production.
safety.ok: Typical safety for static steel structures.
safety.veryHigh: Very high safety. Consider weight optimization.

notes.deflectionLow: This is quite flexible (below L/150) and may cause alignment issues.
notes.deflectionHigh: Very stiff in terms of deflection (L/400 and above).
notes.stress: Computed bending stress is about {sigma} MPa. Safety factor is based on yield strength.
notes.fatigue: If the design sees fatigue or dynamic loads, static safety alone is insufficient; check fatigue limits and stress concentrations.
notes.local: Connections, weld roots, and section changes can cause local stress peaks; this check uses nominal section values.

diagram.title: Bending Moment Diagram (schematic)
diagram.empty: This section shows the schematic moment diagram for a simply supported beam with a central point load. Fill the inputs to render it.
diagram.description: The diagram shows moment rising to Mmax ≈ {value} kN·m at midspan and dropping to zero at the supports.

header.title: Fluids & HVAC Quick Pack
header.description: Three fast checks: (1) Reynolds, friction factor, and pressure loss for water, (2) duct diameter from velocity method, (3) ACH to flow conversion. For concept sizing; use standards for detailed design.

pipe.title: 1) Water Reynolds, f, and Pressure Drop (Darcy-Weisbach)
pipe.note: Assumptions: water at 20°C (ρ=1000 kg/m³, μ=1 cP). Δp = f·(L/D)·ρv²/2. Minor losses, fittings, and temperature effects are excluded.

duct.title: 2) Duct Velocity Method (equivalent diameter)
duct.note: Typical velocities: offices 4–6 m/s, industrial 6–10 m/s. Check manufacturer catalogs for noise and loss; elbows/dampers add extra losses.

ach.title: 3) Air Changes per Hour (ACH) ↔ Flow
ach.note: Typical ACH: offices 4–8, classrooms 6–10, labs 8–15. Check building codes and indoor air quality standards.

notFound.title: Page not found
notFound.description: This link may have been removed or moved. Use the Calculator Library to keep exploring.

faq.title: Frequently asked questions
faq.description: Quick answers about calculators, reporting, standards, and safety assumptions.

items.q: How accurate are the calculators?
items.a: They follow published formulas and checks, but inputs and assumptions are yours. Verify against your standards.

items.q: Are the default values real?
items.a: Defaults are example values to get you started. Replace them with your project data.

items.q: Why do I see validation warnings?
items.a: Warnings flag out-of-range inputs, missing units, or inconsistent selections.

items.q: Can I share a calculation with my team?
items.a: Use Share & Report to generate a link or download a PDF summary.

items.q: Do tools work offline?
items.a: Most calculations run in the browser; reference content and updates need an internet connection.

items.q: What is included in the PDF report?
items.a: Inputs, results, formula, assumptions, references, and any charts/diagrams generated by the tool.

items.q: Can I export diagrams as images?
items.a: Yes. Use the diagram export buttons to download PNG or SVG for reports.

items.q: Is my report stored on your servers?
items.a: No. Reports are generated locally in your browser unless explicitly shared.

items.q: Can I edit the report template?
items.a: Not yet. We are working on customizable report layouts.

items.q: How do I include a report in a project?
items.a: Save the calculation to a project and open the report from the project view.

items.q: Which standards are referenced?
items.a: We reference commonly used ISO/DIN/ASME tables; each tool lists sources in its notes.

items.q: Are standards always up to date?
items.a: We update periodically, but you should verify the latest revision for critical work.

items.q: Do you provide full standards text?
items.a: No. We only show derived tables and summaries; purchase the official standard for full detail.

items.q: What if a standard is missing?
items.a: Send a request via Support or the tool request form.

items.q: How are material properties chosen?
items.a: Typical room-temperature values from handbooks and standards; confirm with supplier data.

items.q: Which unit systems are supported?
items.a: Metric is primary; some tools offer imperial options.

items.q: How does unit conversion work?
items.a: Values are converted via base units with fixed factors; rounding is for display only.

items.q: Why do I see unit mismatch errors?
items.a: The formula output unit does not match the expected unit. Check inputs and symbols.

items.q: Can I mix units?
items.a: Use consistent units in a tool; convert first using the Unit Converter.

items.q: What about significant digits?
items.a: We display rounded values, but calculations use full precision.

items.q: Is this a certified engineering tool?
items.a: No. It is a decision aid; you remain responsible for final design.

items.q: Can I use results for safety-critical designs?
items.a: Use as a preliminary check and validate with standards and a licensed engineer.

items.q: How should I cite the results?
items.a: Include the tool name, version/date, inputs, assumptions, and references in your report.

items.q: Do you store my calculations?
items.a: Saved calculations live in your browser only; use private mode for sensitive work.

items.q: Who is liable for design decisions?
items.a: You are responsible for verifying outputs and compliance.

topics.title: M12 10.9 bolt torque and lubrication
topics.author: Ayşe Yılmaz
topics.details: There is a gap between table values and actual tightening. How do torque wrench calibration and lubrication choice affect torque?

topics.title: Post-weld deflection on S235 plate
topics.author: Mehmet A.
topics.details: After welding a 300x500x10 mm plate with a corner weld, deflection appeared; any fixture and preheat advice?

topics.title: Surface roughness for H8/d9 fit
topics.author: Selin K.
topics.details: I picked H8/d9 for Ø25 hole/shaft. What surface roughness should I target to avoid loosening in press fit?

m12-civata-torku.text: DIN table gives dry values; if you use lubrication, drop by 20-25%. Calibrate your torque wrench yearly.
Typical ~90 Nm for M12 10.9 (dry). With lubrication 65-70 Nm is enough. Keep surfaces clean.
If you use a slip washer, friction drops; reduce torque. You can verify preload with turn-of-nut.

kaynak-sonrasi-sehim.text: Tack symmetrically and weld alternately, then fill in. A 120-150°C preheat helps.
Try welding with a reverse camber. Clamping in a fixture can also help.

h8d9-yuzey-puruzluluk.text: Ra 1.6-3.2 µm usually works. Cleanliness and deburring are critical.
